items.content_html:
Detail

This Pull Request has been created because when rails tries to resolve the database url, it tries use the parsed url's scheme. If we're using an SQLite database, there is no URL, but there is a file path. While using the default SQLite, we get an undefined method to_sym' for nil (NoMethodError)error, since there is no.schemefor a filepath. This PR addresses this. Since the default database is SQLite, this code change sets the default adapter tosqlite3` if the URL fails to resolve.
items.title: add sqlite3 as default in case url does not resolve

Motivation / Background

This pull request removes the gem_ruby_version method to handle RubyGem versions since Ruby 3.2.0 installs RubyGems 3.4.1 as a default gem. We can always use the Gem.ruby_version now.

Detail

The following default gems are updated.
RubyGems 3.4.1

Additional information

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

Implement ActionCable::TestHelper block-wise assertions in terms of #capture_broadcasts. This change inlines the private #new_broadcasts_from method contents into the #capture_broadcasts method, and uses #capture_broadcasts at all the previous #new_broadcasts_from call sites. This consolidation enables the removal of some JSON-parsing duplication across the other method implementations.

Detail

The test file changes were necessary to account for JSON-encoded String values (for example, transforming hello into "hello"). Since the broadcast documentation explicitly mentions that the message value will later be JSON encoded, this shouldn't be a backwards incompatible change.

Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:

  • This Pull Request is related to one change. Unrelated changes should be opened in separate PRs.
  • Commit message has a detailed description of what changed and why. If this PR fixes a related issue include it in the commit message. Ex: [Fix #issue-number]
  • Tests are added or updated if you fix a bug or add a feature.
  • CHANGELOG files are updated for the changed libraries if there is a behavior change or additional feature. Minor bug fixes and documentation changes should not be included.
items.title: Refactor `ActionCable::TestHelper` block-wise assertions

items.content_html:
Tested this over here, but I feel pretty confident it keeps most of the desired behavior.

Auto-label PRs

  • When a Pull request is created or updated, add a label based on file paths changed
  • Labels will update if there is a change to the PR, e.g. rebase, etc
  • This is the only job (unfortunately) that will add a status check to a PR
    • We can roll it into an existing workflow to avoid that, and make it continue-on-error

Stale

  • Runs once a day
  • Ignores PRs
  • Ignore issues with "exempt" labels
  • Adds "stale" label after 90 days with a comment
  • Closes 1 week later with no comment

Unstale

  • Triggered on update to issue or issue comment
  • Skips if the actor is the bot itself (avoid loop from add label -> unstale)
  • Checks for "stale" label and removes if exists

More info needed

  • Runs daily
  • Must add "more-info-needed" label manually (unchanged current process)
  • After 2 weeks of no update,
  • Uses the "stale" action to instead close the issue immediately
    • TODO: remove "more-info-needed" label in unstale job (sorry just noticed this when opening the PR)

Sorry I hit submit before finishing the description.

Opening this now to get some feedback, but we probably want to remove / disable the old probot before merging this.

This is something I've wanted to do for a while, it gives us more control over the changes which influence the Issues team work and processes. Plus the old bot is likely running on some very outdated software, and on a physical machine someone is paying for.
items.title: Migrate from rails-probot to Actions

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

As explained in the Mozilla documentation:

When a user reloads the browser, the browser will send conditional requests for validating to the origin server. But it's not necessary to revalidate those kinds of static resources even when a user reloads the browser, because they're never modified. immutable tells a cache that the response is immutable while it's fresh and avoids those kinds of unnecessary conditional requests to the server.

See: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/Headers/Cache-Control
and https://www.keycdn.com/blog/cache-control-immutable

I believe it's an effective and straightforward approach to improve performance.

For instance, GitHub is already using it in production.

Following @dhh's PR #52883

Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:

  • This Pull Request is related to one change. Unrelated changes should be opened in separate PRs.
  • Commit message has a detailed description of what changed and why. If this PR fixes a related issue include it in the commit message. Ex: [Fix #issue-number]
  • Tests are added or updated if you fix a bug or add a feature.
  • CHANGELOG files are updated for the changed libraries if there is a behavior change or additional feature. Minor bug fixes and documentation changes should not be included.
items.title: Include the immutable directive in the cache-control header

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

This Pull Request has been created because it's currently cumbersome to test that a certain code block/action triggers an ActiveSupport::Notifications::Event to be emitted. It would be ideal to have some helpers to assert against such event emission. Have heard such helpers could be helpful internal to Rails as well.

Co-authored by @yishus

Detail

This Pull Request adds a new test helpers module called ActiveSupport::Notifications::EventAssertions.

Additional information

  • An earlier form of these test helpers has been in use in production CI for our Rails application for over a month.
  • Attempted to include method level documentation with a similar style to nearby code.

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

Rails main branch requires Ruby 3.2.0, we can also update the RuboCop TargetRubyVersion to 3.2. In Ruby 3.2, the Set class was made built-in, so it no longer requires require 'set',

https://www.ruby-lang.org/en/news/2022/12/25/ruby-3-2-0-released/

Set is now available as a builtin class without the need for require "set"

Detail

It addresses the following Lint/RedundantRequireStatement not to run require "set".
The reason why this cop auto correction requires -A is related to the 'pp, so it is safe to use this option to remove set`.

https://docs.rubocop.org/rubocop/cops_lint.html#safety-23

This cop’s autocorrection is unsafe because if require 'pp' is removed from one file, NameError can be encountered when another file uses PP.pp

$ bundle exec rubocop -A

... snip ...

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

TL;DR redirect_to and assert_redirect_to both currently accept non-redirect status codes

Detail

Currently, redirect_to and assert_redirected_to will gladly accept "nonsensical" status values, e.g. :bad_request. I say nonsensical because using redirect_to implies that you intend to, well, redirect! But browsers (and turbo) will not process these responses as redirects because their HTTP response status falls outside the 3XX range

Additional information

A potentially much better option would be to change ActionController::Redirecting#redirect_to to raise an error upon encountering a non-3XX. I didn't tackle that but would be happy to give it a shot.

This gotcha is mitigated to some extent by this helpful note in the docs

Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:

  • This Pull Request is related to one change. Unrelated changes should be opened in separate PRs.
  • Commit message has a detailed description of what changed and why. If this PR fixes a related issue include it in the commit message. Ex: [Fix #issue-number]
  • Tests are added or updated if you fix a bug or add a feature.
  • CHANGELOG files are updated for the changed libraries if there is a behavior change or additional feature. Minor bug fixes and documentation changes should not be included
items.title: Change `assert_redirected_to` to reject non-3XX status codes

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

Currently, for a regular count query, like Account.order(id: :desc).count, ActiveRecord already removes the ORDER BY predicate. However, it does not if it needs the subquery_for_count alias approach. For example, running the test case I add in a8a63f7:

Using trilogy
Run options: --seed 17113

# Running:

F

Failure:
CalculationsTest#test_no_order_by_in_subquery_for_count [test/cases/calculations_test.rb:308]:
Expected /ORDER BY/ to not match "SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (SELECT 1 AS one FROM `accounts` ORDER BY `accounts`.`id` DESC LIMIT 10) subquery_for_count".


bin/test test/cases/calculations_test.rb:305

Detail

This Pull Request removes the ORDER BY clause when building the subquery for count and will produce a query like

SELECT COUNT(*) FROM (SELECT 1 AS one FROM `accounts` LIMIT 10) subquery_for_count

Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:

  • This Pull Request is related to one change. Unrelated changes should be opened in separate PRs.
  • Commit message has a detailed description of what changed and why. If this PR fixes a related issue include it in the commit message. Ex: [Fix #issue-number]
  • Tests are added or updated if you fix a bug or add a feature.
  • CHANGELOG files are updated for the changed libraries if there is a behavior change or additional feature. Minor bug fixes and documentation changes should not be included.
items.title: Unscope `ORDER BY` predicate in `subquery_for_count`

items.content_html:
Fixes #52459

The current default bin/dev execs the Rails server directly and doesn't support Procfiles. Therefore, gems like jsbundling-rails, tailwindcss-rails, and soon solid_queue need to overwrite the bin/dev script with their own version.

With this new version, gems can skip overwriting the bin/dev script and add to the Procfile instead.

  • It installs Foreman if needed
  • Execs directly into rail server if no procfile is present
  • Spawns Foreman in the background to allow breakpoints in the Rails process without Foreman eating the inputs or interleaving its output.

bin/dev vs command

With the increase in complexity, it might make sense to pull the bulk of bin/dev inside a Rails command and have bin/dev be a shim. This would allow us to push updates in the future if necessary.

I've included both the bin/dev script and the Rails command version for discussion. If we decide to keep one of them, I'll amend the commit to remove the other and update the changelog accordingly.

If we go the command route, I'm unsure how to name it. I chose devserver temporarily. dev:server or server:dev sound nice from a user perspective, but they don't quite fit into the server or dev command.

Notes

If we merge this we also have to remove the bin/dev install phase on jsbundling-rails and tailwindcss-rails.

Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:

  • This Pull Request is related to one change. Unrelated changes should be opened in separate PRs.
  • Commit message has a detailed description of what changed and why. If this PR fixes a related issue include it in the commit message. Ex: [Fix #issue-number]
  • Tests are added or updated if you fix a bug or add a feature.
  • CHANGELOG files are updated for the changed libraries if there is a behavior change or additional feature. Minor bug fixes and documentation changes should not be included.
items.title: Add enhanced default bin/dev

items.content_html:
Motivation / Background

Relates to discussion #52677.

Currently, the Rails console prompt is colored according to the following rules:

  • on dev, the prompt becomes blue
  • on test, the prompt becomes blue
  • on prod, the prompt becomes red
  • on non-standard environments (like staging), the prompt remains white

I believe that keeping the prompt not colored for non-standard environments is rather ugly. Thus, I have decided to open this PR.

Detail

Looking at the IRB code, the available colors are:

  • black (not suitable for obvious reasons)
  • red (already in use)
  • green (not suitable, see #50855)
  • yellow (possible candidate)
  • blue (already in use)
  • magenta (possible candidate)
  • cyan (possible candidate)
  • white (not suitable for obvious reasons)

The 3 possible candidates are thus yellow, magenta and cyan. Here are some screenshots:

Yellow:

Cyan:

Magenta:

I have decided to go with Magenta purely for personal preferences, but I am open to other opinions, especially regarding more color blind friendly combinations.

Additional information

Checklist

Before submitting the PR make sure the following are checked:

  • This Pull Request is related to one change. Unrelated changes should be opened in separate PRs.
  • Commit message has a detailed description of what changed and why. If this PR fixes a related issue include it in the commit message. Ex: [Fix #issue-number]
  • Tests are added or updated if you fix a bug or add a feature.
  • CHANGELOG files are updated for the changed libraries if there is a behavior change or additional feature. Minor bug fixes and documentation changes should not be included.
items.title: Colorize console prompt on non standard environments
